bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 167, Number 201 (Thursday, November 18, 2021)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. BURCHETT:H.J. Res 66.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I Section VIII of the United States Constitution[Page H6610]

item.name: Constitution, Civil Rights, and Civil Liberties Subcommittee

item.title: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to limit the number of terms that a Member of Congress may serve.

item.name: Constitution, Civil Rights, and Civil Liberties Subcommittee

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on the Constitution, Civil Rights, and Civil Liberties.
Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.

summary.text: This joint resolution proposes a constitutional amendment limiting Members of the House of Representatives to three terms and Senators to two terms. The term limits do not apply to any person serving a term as a Member of Congress on the date the amendment is ratified.

bill.title: Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States to limit the number of terms that a Member of Congress may serve.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
